centralQuestion: Should the government continue its trend of raising the debt ceiling indefinitely?

reasons.description: Raising (or suspending) the ceiling prevents a U.S. default and severe economic fallout for households and markets.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Explainer: How could a US debt ceiling default hit regular Americans?'
PBS NewsHour: 'How a debt default could affect you'

reasons.description: The debt ceiling is an outdated and ineffective constraint; routinely raising or abolishing it avoids self-inflicted crises over already-authorized spending.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'The economics of the debt ceiling debate'
Council on Foreign Relations: 'The U.S. Has Every Reason It Needs to Drop the Debt Ceiling—Both at Home and Abroad'

reasons.description: Debt-ceiling brinkmanship directly raises Treasury borrowing costs, disrupts liquidity, and has contributed to ratings actions; prompt increases reduce these costs.

sources.title: GAO: 'DEBT LIMIT: Market Response to Recent Impasses Underscores Need to Consider Alternative Approaches'
Reuters: 'Fitch downgrades U.S. credit rating to AA+ citing expected fiscal deterioration'

reasons.description: Regularly raising the ceiling supports global financial stability and the dollar’s reserve-currency role by avoiding periodic brinkmanship.

sources.title: Council on Foreign Relations: 'What Happens When the U.S. Hits Its Debt Ceiling?'
PBS NewsHour: 'Here’s what would happen to the global economy if the U.S. defaults on its debt'

reasons.description: Raising the ceiling allows payment of existing legal obligations already authorized by Congress; it does not authorize new spending.

sources.title: Congressional Budget Office: 'The Debt Ceiling and Its Impact on Federal Debt'
PBS NewsHour: 'The U.S. debt ceiling, explained'

objections.description: Indefinite hikes enable fiscal profligacy and reduce pressure for spending restraint or structural reforms.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: 'Social Security, the debt limit, and the Washington Monument strategy'
POLITICO: 'House GOP passes its debt bill, upping pressure on Biden'

objections.description: Repeated increases without credible consolidation can damage U.S. creditworthiness and raise borrowing costs.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Moody’s downgrades U.S. credit rating to Aa1, citing fiscal deterioration'
Reuters: 'U.S. ability to reach major fiscal reforms questioned as debt-limit step not enough'

objections.description: Public opinion often favors tying any increase to deficit reduction; unconditional raises may lack political legitimacy.

sources.title: PBS NewsHour: 'New poll shows majority of adults in U.S. say they are concerned about debt limit, don’t understand latest negotiations'
POLITICO: 'A debt limit fight helped Democrats in 2011. This time, it’s a more complicated story'

objections.description: Rising interest costs from continued debt growth risk crowding out other priorities and creating long-run vulnerabilities.

sources.title: Congressional Budget Office: 'The 2025 Long-Term Budget Outlook'
International Monetary Fund: 'Managing Risky Debt in an Aging World'

objections.description: The debt limit provides leverage to force bipartisan fiscal negotiations; removing or endlessly increasing it could weaken discipline.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: 'The debt limit is not a mortal threat to the U.S. economy'
POLITICO: 'Senate Republicans will stand firm on debt ceiling, Mike Lee says'

research.title: Journal of Money, Credit and Banking: 'Treasury Safety, Liquidity, and Money Premium Dynamics: Evidence from Debt Limit Impasses'
research.description: Peer-reviewed study documenting that during U.S. debt-limit impasses, the safety and liquidity of Treasuries temporarily deteriorate, eroding their money premium.

research.title: International Economic Review: 'Debt Ceilings With Fiscal Intransparency and Imperfect Electoral Accountability'
research.description: Theoretical analysis of optimal debt ceilings in a political-agency model with fiscal intransparency and imperfect voter accountability.

research.title: American Economic Journal: Macroeconomics: 'Fiscal Rules and the Sovereign Default Premium'
research.description: Model-based evidence that well-designed fiscal rules (e.g., debt or spread brakes) reduce sovereign default premia and improve welfare.

research.title: Public Budgeting & Finance: 'Fiscal Stance, Fiscal Rules, and Public Debt Dynamics in Advanced Economies'
research.description: Comparative, peer-reviewed assessment of fiscal rules and debt dynamics across advanced economies; includes context on the U.S. debt ceiling’s role and frequency of increases.
